name.text: Finding the Area of a Regular Pentagon

questiontext.text:
Find the area of the figure below, centered at \(O\).

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-40, 40, 40, -40], axis: false, showCopyright: false }); /* Centre point O */ var O = board.create('point', [0, 0], { name: 'O', fixed: true, visible: false }); /* Pentagon vertices (numerical, fixed shape) */ var A = board.create('point', [0, 25.5], {visible: false}); var B = board.create('point', [24.2, 7.9], {visible: false}); var C = board.create('point', [14.8, -20.6], {visible: false}); var D = board.create('point', [-14.8, -20.6], {visible: false}); var E = board.create('point', [-24.2, 7.9], {visible: false}); /* Pentagon */ board.create('polygon', [A, B, C, D, E], { borders: {strokeColor: 'black'}, fillColor: 'none' }); /* Radius lines */ board.create('segment', [O, C], { strokeColor: 'black', straightFirst: false, straightLast: false }); board.create('segment', [O, B], { strokeColor: 'black', straightFirst: false, straightLast: false }); /* Labels */ board.create('text', [-1, -10, "{#slant#} cm"], { fontSize: 12, fixed: true }); board.create('text', [-0.2, 2, "O"], { fontSize: 12, fixed: true }); /* Base BC */ board.create('segment', [B, C], { strokeColor: 'black' }); board.create('text', [ function(){ return B.X(); }, function(){ return B.Y() - 15; }, "{#base_length#} cm" ], { fontSize: 12, fixed: true }); /* Perpendicular height from O to BC */ var midpoint = board.create('midpoint', [B, C], {visible: false}); board.create('segment', [O, midpoint], { strokeColor: 'black', dash: 1 }); /* Right angle marker */ board.create('nonreflexangle', [B, midpoint, O], { radius: 3, type: 'square', name: '', fixed: true }); [[/jsxgraph]]

\(\text{Area} =\) [[input:ans1]] \(\text{cm}^2\) [[feedback:prt1]]

[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

To calculate the area of the pentagon, divide the shape into five identical isosceles triangles by joining each vertex to the centre \(O\).

Each triangle has:

  • base length \( {@base_length@} \) cm
  • two equal sides of length \( {@slant@} \) cm

To find the perpendicular height of one triangle, we split it into two right-angled triangles. The hypotenuse is the slanted side, and half the base is \[ \frac{{@base_length@}}{2}. \]

Using Pythagoras’ theorem: \[ h = \sqrt{({@slant@})^2 - \left(\frac{{@base_length@}}{2}\right)^2}. \]

The area of one triangle is therefore \[ \frac{1}{2} \times {@base_length@} \times h. \]

Since the pentagon consists of five identical triangles, its total area is \[ 5 \times \frac{1}{2} \times {@base_length@} \times h = {@ta@}. \]

\[ \boxed{\text{Area} = {@ta@}\text{ cm}^2} \]

questionnote.text:
Purpose of the question

This question assesses students’ ability to calculate the area of a regular pentagon by decomposing it into five congruent isosceles triangles with a common centre. The emphasis is on correct geometric reasoning rather than memorisation of a single formula.

Mathematical approach

Students are expected to recognise that the pentagon can be split into five identical triangles, each with base equal to the side length of the pentagon and height obtained by dropping a perpendicular from the centre to the base. The perpendicular height must be calculated using Pythagoras’ theorem.

Use of the diagram

  • The JSXGraph figure is centred at \(O\) and is provided to support visualisation.
  • The slanted sides represent the distance from the centre to a vertex.
  • The dashed segment represents the perpendicular height used in the area calculation.
  • The diagram is illustrative only and is not used for validation.

Design choices

  • All values are generated to ensure a valid right triangle.
  • No conditional statements are used in the question variables.
  • Common incorrect strategies are anticipated and handled in the PRT.

Common student difficulties

  • Using the slanted side instead of the perpendicular height.
  • Using half the base as the height.
  • Calculating the area of only one triangle and forgetting to multiply by five.

questiondescription.text:
Monica Sherily

This question is on finding the area of a regular pentagon. The learner is required to observe the diagram and identify the various dimensions then calculate the area of the pentagon. Guide them to first find the area of one triangle formed by drawing lines from the center to each vertex, and then multiply it by five to get the total area of the pentagon.
